thread.title: UCLA: Bruins on eerily familiar path this season
thread.title_full: UCLA: Bruins on eerily familiar path this season - Press Enterprise

author: JOEY KAUFMAN
title: UCLA: Bruins on eerily familiar path this season
text:
BY JOEY KAUFMAN / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 18, 2015 Updated: Oct. 19, 2015 2:27 p.m. UCLA: Bruins on eerily familiar path this season Print Photo Share Pin It More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Related article » LOS ANGELES – The parallels look similar.
Last season, UCLA, once comfortably a top-10 team, stumbled twice in early October to Utah and Oregon and dropped out of the top 25 as a result.
Yet again, the Bruins have fallen twice this month, this time to Pac-12 foes Arizona State and Stanford.
In almost identical fashion, a team that had climbed as high as No. 7 in the polls is left unranked after Week 8.
“One thing is try to stay the course if you believe the course is the right course, and we do,” UCLA coach Jim Mora said.
Following the two-game slide last season, the Bruins went on to win five straight games, including against USC, nearly winning the South Division before a loss to Stanford in the regular-season finale.
If players and coaches want the parallels to continue, they'll need to turn things around quickly as No. 20 Cal awaits Thursday night at the Rose Bowl.
“We’re still confident,” senior receiver Jordan Payton said. “We still play hard. We just have to clean the mistakes up. The little things are killing us.”
Of the next four games, the Golden Bears are the only ranked foe that awaits, perhaps giving the Bruins (4-2, 1-2 Pac-12) an opportunity to reverse course and follow a similar script.
“If you believe in what you're doing, you do it and you keep trying to do it better, make improvements, get rid of the things that aren't working and improve on the things that are working, you try to put your players in the best position you can,” Mora said. “But you don't panic. So we’ve learned that and we’re going to be better for it.”
REVISITING TARGETING
UCLA has had one of its players ejected for targeting in two of the past four games.
Against BYU, sophomore linebacker Kenny Young was whistled for targeting Tanner Magnum when the Cougars’ quarterback slid on his team’s opening drive.
The latest targeting penalty came against Stanford when receiver Kenny Walker was called for targeting linebacker Blake Martinez. As quarterback Josh Rosen was running downfield, Walker threw a block on Martinez, hitting him in the neck.
The targeting rule was implemented in 2008, and its more controversial element – an automatic ejection – was added in 2013.
